title: former myanmar beauty queen joins armed struggle against junta
story: A former Myanmar beauty queen has joined the ranks of ethnic insurgents opposing the ruling junta, posting photos of herself on Facebook in a jungle setting with an assault rifle. A military takeover and the ousting of the civilian government on February 1 plunged the Southeast Asian country into crisis, and close to 800 people have been killed by security forces in a violent post-coup crackdown. Today marks 100 days since we lost everything, wrote Htar Htet Htet, 32, in her social media post. “The time has come to fight back.”The coup ended the country's decade-long experiment with democracy after half a century of military rule.There have been several reports of young activists fleeing a military manhunt and taking refuge in the restive border homelands of Myanmar’s ethnic minorities. Others are believed to have chosen voluntarily to take up arms training alongside rebels who have waged insurgencies against the military for decades as they seek to secure more autonomy for their communities. In 2013, Htar Htet Htet represented Myanmar in the first Miss Grand International beauty pageant in Thailand.Before swapping into black combat fatigues, and heading to the jungle, she also worked as a gymnastics instructor. “I will fight back as much as I can. I am ready and prepared to give up everything. I am even ready to pay with my life,” she wrote. Anti-coup street protests are continuing across Myanmar, despite the risk of injury or death at the hands of junta forces. The civil disobedience movement, which has seen many workers in multiple professions strike against the military regime, is also ongoing. More than 11,000 academics and other university staff opposed to the junta have been suspended after going on strike in protest against military rule, a teachers' group said this week. The suspensions come as the resumption of universities after a year closed due to the coronavirus epidemic prompts a new confrontation between the army and the staff and students, who are calling for boycotts.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: israel military draws plan ground invasion gaza
story: The Israeli military was drawing up plans to send troops into Gaza on Thursday as it continued to exchange fire with Hamas fighters through the night, while in Israeli cities a fresh wave of riots led to 400 arrests.The Israeli Defense Forces said it had deployed two infantry units and one armoured unit to the border with Gaza, and that a ground operations plan would be submitted to military chiefs later today, ahead of approval by the Israeli government. The decision on whether to invade Gaza is up to the Israeli government, rather than the military, and it carries significant political implications for the cabinet as it would substantially increase the risk of far more Israeli casualties.Hamas has said it fired a large rocket at Israel's Ramon airport near Eilat, where incoming passenger flights were erted after waves of rocket launches towards the main airport near Tel Aviv.A spokesman for Hamas' armed wing announced the launch of the 250 kilogram (550 pound) rocket and demanded that all international airlines immediately halt their flights to any airports in the Jewish state.Despite diplomatic efforts to ease the crisis, which US President Joe Biden said he hoped would end sooner than later, hundreds of rockets flew across the Gaza Strip overnight.James Cleverly, the UK Middle East minister, described the level of rocket fire from Gaza into Israel as unprecedented, and called on all sides to step back from the brink.Air raid warnings went off across Israel, including for the first time in the country's north, though on Thursday an Israeli military spokesman said this had been a false alarm. Israel's air force said it had launched multiple strikes, targeting what it described as locations linked to the counterintelligence infrastructure of Hamas, the Islamist group that controls Gaza, as well as the house of Iyad Tayeb, one of the movement's commanders.There were reports from Gaza on Thursday that Israel had struck a Hamas-controlled ministry of finance building as well as a Hamas-controlled bank. IDF strikes also destroyed a multi-storey tower housing Palestinian television channel Al-Aqsa, which was set up by Hamas.It's the same atmosphere of 2014, Saud Abu Ramadan, a freelance journalist in Gaza City, said.He was referring to the bloody 7-week war that followed the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers by Hamas members. Over 2,000 Palestinians and widespread destruction was inflicted on Gaza's infrastructure. Warplanes are buzzing, and people are just trying to keep their heads down,” he added.Israel meanwhile announced that Palestinian militants had launched around 1,600 rockets into its territory since Monday evening.Many in Israel also holed up in shelters as waves of rockets hit its heartland, some blown out of the sky by Iron Dome interceptors.All of Israel is under attack. It's a very scary situation to be in, said Margo Aronovic, a 26-year-old student, in Tel Aviv.We're coping, sitting at home, hoping it will be OK, said Motti Haim, a resident of the central town of Beer Yaakov and father of two children. It's not simple running to the shelter. It's not easy with the kids.In Gaza, 83 people have so far been killed, the health ministry controlled by the territory's Islamist rulers Hamas said Thursday.The dead included 17 children, while 487 people have been wounded, the ministry said.In Israel, the casualty rate has risen to seven following the death of an Israeli soldier and a five-year-old boy who was killed by rocket fire. On Wednesday, Hamas announced the death of its military chief in Gaza City, Bassem Issa, with the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) saying they had killed several other senior Hamas figures as well.Health authorities in Gaza said they were investigating the deaths of several people overnight who they said may have inhaled poisonous gas. Samples were being examined and they had yet to draw any final conclusions, they said.There were 400 arrests across Israeli cities such as Acre, Haifa and Lod overnight in what the president of Israel, Reuven Rivlin, described as a civil war between Arab and Jewish residents. Israeli TV footage showed Jewish rioters pulling an Arab man from his car and beating him severely, in what was described as a lynching. In the mixed Jewish-Arab city of Lod, Arab rioters torched cars, a school and a synagogue. Israeli police said two people were shot and wounded in Lod and an Israeli Jew was stabbed.Mr Rivlin, in unusually strong language, denounced what he described as a pogrom in which an incited and bloodthirsty Arab mob had injured people and attacked sacred Jewish spaces.In the occupied West Bank, a Palestinian man was killed during a confrontation with Israeli soldiers near the northern city of Nablus, the Palestinian health ministry said Thursday.What has been happening these last few days in Israeli towns is unacceptable... Nothing justifies the lynching of Arabs by Jews and nothing justifies the lynching of Jews by Arabs, Mr Netanyahu said, adding that Israel was fighting a battle on two fronts.While United Nations and Egyptian officials have said that cease-fire efforts are underway, there were no signs of progress on Thursday.UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres condemned the indiscriminate launching of rockets from civilian areas in Gaza toward Israeli population centers, but he also urged Israel to show maximum restraint.Israel echoed the UN's sentiments in a letter to Mr Guterres.I call upon the international community to unequivocally condemn the indiscriminate attacks by terrorist groups in the Gaza Strip against Israeli civilians and population centers and to support Israel's fundamental right to self-defense, the country's ambassador to the UN and to the US, Gilad Erdan, said in the letter.The State of Israel is not interested in an escalation. However, Israel has the right and duty to defend its people and sovereignty and will continue to do so vigorously, he added.Amid fears the violence could spiral further out of control, Washington planned to send an envoy, Hady Amr, for talks with Israel and Palestinians.My expectation and hope is this will be closing down sooner than later, but Israel has a right to defend itself, Mr Biden said on Wednesday.Mr Cleverly, Britain's minister for the Middle East, called on Hamas, Israel and the Palestinians to step back from the brink of what he cast as a terrible escalation, and told the Islamist group to cease rocket attacks on the Jewish state.It is important for both sides to take a step back, Mr Cleverly told Sky News.We have seen, however, an unprecedented level of rocket attack into Israel, he said. We want to see the rocket attacks stop.British Airways cancelled its flights to and from Tel Aviv on Thursday, the latest international carrier to avoid flying to Israel.The safety and security of our colleagues and customers is always our top priority, and we continue to monitor the situation closely, British Airways said.United Airlines, Delta Air Lines and American Airlines on Wednesday all cancelled flights between the United States and Tel Aviv. Lufthansa follows on Thursday.Incoming flights from Ben Gurion International Airport have been erted to the Ramon airfield in the country's far south, Israel's Transportation Ministry said. The airfield was designed to serve as a wartime alternative to its main international gateway outside Tel Aviv.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: now moment shakeup unionism northern ireland
story: Northern Ireland’s biggest party, the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), was already embroiled in its first competitive leadership battle, after elected representatives ousted Arlene Foster. Now, the province’s second biggest unionist party, the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP), is seeking a new leader too, following the resignation of Steve Aiken, a former Royal Navy submarine commander who was in post for just eighteen months.Foster’s overthrow was an acrimonious affair and she has since announced that she intends to leave the DUP when she stands down officially. In contrast, according to the UUP at least, Aiken left after “long conversations” about the future of the party that took place “face to face”. His potential successor, Doug Beattie, said “He made the decision himself. It was his decision to take.”Aiken’s departure seemed to be an amicable affair, but it was prompted, at least in part, by the DUP’s move against Foster. The UUP dominated politics in Northern Ireland until the early 2000s and, since then, it has been desperate to regain control of unionism. In theory, the DUP’s messy coup against its leader and the secretive leadership contest that ensued provided the Ulster Unionists’ with an ideal opportunity.At the same time, the party’s electoral performances under Aiken were among the worst in its history and there was little confidence that he could inspire a ‘surge’ to challenge its rivals. Recent polling suggested the DUP was losing supporters to the Traditional Unionist Voice (TUV), which opposes power-sharing with Sinn Fein, and the Alliance Party, which claims it is ‘agnostic’ on the Union, instead of the UUP.When the DUP’s elected representatives challenged Foster to hold a leadership contest and she resigned, it looked like the party would see a resurgence of hardline, religious conservatives, in the mould of Ian Paisley. It was unclear whether the coup was inspired chiefly by political disagreements, policy differences or factionalism, but it added urgency to the Ulster Unionists’ deliberations about their leadership.The DUP must now choose between the Stormont MLA Edwin Poots, a member of Paisley’s evangelical Free Presbyterian sect, who is cast as the traditionalist candidate, and Sir Jeffrey Donaldson MP, who defected from the UUP and is viewed as a moderniser. The competitors are not allowed to speak to the media while the contest is ongoing, so their campaign teams have communicated their plans to the public via anonymous briefings.The Ulster Unionists are keen for their selection process to look transparent in comparison. Steve Aiken spoke at length to the media, explaining how he sees the party’s future, and Doug Beattie, who is, as yet, the only declared candidate, was interviewed on the BBC’s Nolan Show. Beattie is a former army captain, who was awarded a Military Cross for his bravery in Afghanistan. He is viewed as relatively liberal and may be well placed to win votes back from the self-styled ‘progressives’ of the Alliance Party, as well as disillusioned DUP supporters. The challenge, for any Ulster Unionist leader, though, will be to explain clearly what the party stands for. In recent decades, it struggled to persuade voters that it was significantly different from the DUP.Perhaps the key for the party is not to concentrate exclusively on the ide that separates socially liberal and conservative voters in Ulster. There are equally important differences between unionists who want to play a full role in the UK and those who like the trappings of Britishness but are comfortable seeing Northern Ireland as a ‘place apart’ from the rest of the country.The Northern Ireland Protocol is compelling proof that this ‘Ulster nationalist’ attitude makes it easier for Westminster governments to distance the province from mainstream politics. Ulster badly needs a unionist party that is comfortable with the modern world, but remains firm on constitutional issues and makes the integrity of the UK its primary focus. Some commentators claim that Northern Irish unionism is in turmoil, as both of its main parties struggle to appoint leaders to improve their image and boost their electoral performances. It’s important to recognise that unionists also have a valuable opportunity to become more appealing to modern voters and secure the Union into the future.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: tricky topic lady kitty spencer thorny issue inheritance althorp
story: Lady Kitty Spencer has said that attitudes to primogeniture are changing, despite her father’s insistence that she will not inherit Althorp.Earl Spencer, brother to Diana, Princess of Wales, plans to leave the estate to his son, Louis, who will inherit the title despite having three older sisters.The eldest is Lady Kitty, 30, who suggested that her father’s decision was out of step with modern thinking.“Primogeniture can be a tricky topic, because as times are changing, attitudes are as well. We’ve grown up understanding that it’s Louis to inherit, and Louis will do an incredible job,” she told Town &amp Country magazine.Lady Kitty’s comments are the latest contribution to the debate over female heirs. In 2011, the 300-year-old rules of succession to the throne were changed to give equal rights to sons and daughters of any future British monarch. Had the first child of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge been a girl, she would have grown up to become Queen.David Cameron, then Prime Minister, said at the time that “the idea that a younger son should become monarch instead of an elder daughter, simply because he is a man, just isn’t acceptable any more”.Nevertheless, in 2015 Earl Spencer confirmed that he would be sticking with tradition.“If I chose Kitty it would be against all the tradition that goes with Althorp. It’s just the way it is. I get the problems with it as a concept,” he said.“I also get the strengths of it having worked to date. It is still intact. If you go around the chateaux of the Loire or whatever, they are empty. Everything gets split equally through the generations and you end up with a beautiful building with one nice tapestry in it. The whole idea of primogeniture was to keep it together.”Lady Kitty spoke fondly of Althorp, the 90-room house in Northamptonshire that has been the seat of the Spencer family for 19 generations.“We have such an emotional attachment to Althorp. That’s where we would have our Easter egg hunts and our Christmases I have my little vegetable patch, I learnt to ride a horse there, I learnt to ride a bike and to rollerblade. It’s so lovely to look back on the history and think everybody else probably learnt to ride a horse there too.”Critics of the primogeniture system include Lady Kinvara Balfour, who called the system “archaic” and “absolutely mad”, saying it sent a message that “a daughter is a disappointment” and women are second best.Her mother, Lady Tessa, was the eldest child of the 17th Duke of Norfolk but the title and Arundel Castle in West Sussex went to Lady Tessa’s younger brother.For the magazine photoshoot, Lady Kitty, a model and ambassador for Dolce &amp Gabbana, posed in the grounds of Waddesdon Manor in Buckinghamshire, rather than Althorp.She also recalled being thrust into the spotlight when she attended the wedding of her cousin, the Duke of Sussex. Overnight, her Instagram following leapt from 37,000 to half a million.“I woke up the next day and looked at my phone and thought, ‘Whoops, did I take someone else’s by mistake?’ It was very weird and a little overwhelming.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: watch nicola sturgeons back and forth indyref2 messaging matters
story: After the election, Nicola Sturgeon told Boris Johnson her plan for a second independence referendum was now a matter of when, not if, despite the SNP falling short of a majority.However, throughout the campaign for the May 6 election, there were varied messages from the SNP on what a vote for them meant.Sometimes it meant independence, other times it meant backing Ms Sturgeon's handling of the Covid pandemic recovery. So SNP voters may not have voted for the party to back independence, says  columnist Alan Cochrane.Although they played down an independence referendum...the ink on the results had barely dried before Nicola Sturgeon said there was a majority in Scotland for independence and an independence referendum, says Alan Cochrane.Watch the video to see how the SNP mixed their campaign messaging and why it's a big claim by Nicola Sturgeon to say that the results give her a mandate for a second referendum.For more videos from The , subscribe to our YouTube channel. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: david cameron boasts paid far
story: NewsDavid Cameron boasts he was paid far more by Greensill than he was as PMThe former Prime Minister refused to put a figure on his potential payday from the doomed financier - but said the reported figure of £m was "completely absurd"mirrorShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY NewsThe PM gave evidence to the Treasury committee " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeDavid Cameron was paid far more by Greensill Capital than he was as Prime Minsiter, he boasted to MPs today. And he said he didnapost know why he signed off his texts Love DC - but admitted he did so with anyone he knew even at all well. The former Prime Minister was grilled by a Commons committee about his lobbying of ministers on behalf of the now-collapsed financial firm. He admitted: I was paid a generous amount - far more than I was paid as PM. And I had shares - not share options, but shares in the business which vested over the period of time of my contract. So itaposs important for the committee to know that I absolutely had a big economic investment in Greensill. I wanted it to succeed. I wanted it to grow. I havenapost put a number on those things, because ...the amount isnapost particularly germaine to these questions and is a private matter. But the ex-PM insisted his motivation for calls and texts to ministers asking for help on behalf of the firm was not just financial, but because he thought the firm had solutions that were in the interests of the public good.  Asked why he signed off some texts to officials with love DC - the ex-PM said: Anyone I know even at all well I tend to sign off with text messages aposlove DCapos, I don’t know why, I just do. My children say you don’t need to sign off text messages at all. Mr Cameron said he said abided by the rules that were in place, but added: Rules alone are never enough. We learnt that in this place over so many issues, personal conduct and codes of behaviour, and how such conduct and behaviour both appears and can be perceived, these things matter too. I completely accept that former prime ministers are in a dferent position to others because of the office that we held and the influence that continues to bring. We need to think dferently and act dferently. He said lobbying the Government was never intended to be part of his role at Greensill Capital until the coronavirus crisis.In his opening statement to the Commons Treasury Committee, he said: In terms of my role, I was not employed at Greensill as a lobbyist and lobbying the UK Government was never intended to be part of my role. However, in the economic turmoil caused by Covid, the Government, quite rightly, introduced several schemes to help ensure that credit would continue to be expanded to business. The Greensill proposal was to make this even more effective and I believed that it should be considered by Government.FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnDavid CameronPoliticsCoronavirus

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe governmentaposs scientic advisors are holding an urgent meeting today to discuss the growing threat from the Indian Covid iant.The meeting, first reported by i news and confirmed by Boris Johnson, comes after the number of B.. iant cases in the UK almost tripled to  as of May .The newspaper claims new figures today could show the number of cases has tripled again in the last week to around ,. A member of the committee claimed “a delay is possible” to the final phase of lockdown easing in England - which is meant to abolish all legal social distancing rules from June . SAGE meet regularly. Boris Johnson today admitted “we are anxious about it - it has been spreading”.Read an updated version of this story here. The PM said “we’re ruling nothing out” and “there are meetings going on today to consider exactly what we need to do.” The PM insisted “at the moment I can see nothing that dissuades me” from thinking the final stage of ending lockdown rules can happen on June . But he suggested theto “normality” could slip to a later datethe Indian iant “takes off”. Askedmasks and social distancing were going, Boris Johnson said more announcements will be made before the end of the month. He added: I think we have to wait a little bit longer to see how the data is looking but I am cautiously optimistic about that. “Provided this Indian iant doesnapost take off in the way some people fear, I think certainly things could get back much, much closer to normality.” But Tory minister James Cleverly today refused to rule out delaying the end of lockdown beyond June .  Mr Cleverly also refused to rule out the prospect of local lockdowns in areas like Bolton, where the iant is believed to be spreading.But one expert today warned the spread of the coronavirus Indian iant should be viewed as a nationwide problem.Professor James Naismith, from the University of Oxford, said the iant may spread way beyond the local areas where it has been detected. Prof Naismith, who is also a director at the Rosalind Franklin Institute, said: I think we should view it as a country-wide problem. It will get everywhere. We keep learning this lesson, but we know that this will be the case.  Prof Naismith said he did not believe local restrictions would work to contain the iant. He told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: When we tried locally having dferent restrictions in dferent regions that didnapost really make any dference. So I donapost think thinking about a localised strategy for containment will really work. He added: The vaccines donapost % prevent infection for people. What they do, is they almost % prevent hospitalisation and serious illness. We donapost know enough to know yet whether the Indian strain will behave dferently than that. So even the regular virus can infect people who have been vaccinated and sometimes you do get reinfection. And the very, very large number of cases in India mean things that are rare will be detected. Boris Johnson is expected to be asked for more details of the Covid- public inquiry when he faces the TV cameras.The Prime Minister is due to visit a school in Co Durham where he is set to face questions over why the probe will not be launched until next spring. Asked about a possible delay to the June  easing, Foreign Minister James Cleverly told Sky News: “Scientists on SAGE will make assessments, they will report that to government, and we will make decisions based on the data, the evidence they provide. “The Prime Minister and the Health Secretary have always been clear that the easing of restrictions which allows us to get back to normality will be done at a pace and in a way that is safe. “We will always be driven by the data.”FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnConservative PartyRadio University of OxfordJames CleverlyBoris JohnsonJames NaismithR TodayPublic inquiryPoliticsCoronavirus

again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAfter months of stalling, Boris Johnson has finally agreed to establish an inquiry into the coronavirus pandemic. The case for an independent examination of how ministers, scientists and the NHS responded to the biggest public health ­emergency for a century was incontrovertible. We need to know why Britain ended up having one of the highest death tolls in the world, why the NHS was not prepared for such a crisis, why it took so long to provide PPE. Those who have lost loved ones to the virus are rightly furious the Prime Minister has delayed this inquiry until the spring of . If there is, as Mr Johnson has suggested, a strong likelihood of a winter surge then we should have at least an interim investigation now so lessons can be learned which may help prevent further deaths. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  By deferring the inquiry for a year the Prime Minister has clearly calculated the findings will not be published until after the next election. Not for the first time he’s putting his personal interests before those of the country. Fears of war There are concerns the violence in Jerusalem and Gaza could escalate into war. The Israeli military has responded to rocket attacks by Palestinian militants by unleashing a wave of air strikes.  Brokering a ceasefire is imperative and urgentwe are to prevent the loss of more civilian lives and stop the situation descending into a conflict which risks engulfing other parts of the Middle East. The international community must exert whatever influence it has on the Israeli and Palestinian leaders. Then work must once again begin trying to find a lasting settlement based on the two-state solution. Pay a flat fee  Despite earning £, a year it appears Boris Johnson has trouble paying some of his bills on time. Thankfully, the Prime Minister and First Lord of Treasury is not in charge of the nation’s finances. Oh hang on...FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnBoris JohnsonPublic inquiryPoliticsCoronavirus

title: england footie team pay tribute
story: NewsEngland football teams touching tribute to boy, , killed by lightning strikeTalented youth player Jordan Banks, a Liverpool FC fan, was fatally injured in a thunderstorm while taking part in a private coaching session near his home in BlackpoolmirrorShareCommentsByBarnaby KellawayGraeme Murray:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsJordan Banks of Clton Rangers in Blackpool who tragically died after being struck by lightning " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice The England football team has paid tribute to a tragic nine-year-old boy killed by lightning while playing football.Talented youth player Jordan Banks was fatally injured during a thunderstorm. The footy mad youngster is thought to have been taking part in a private coaching session at the time of the tragedy. Thousands of tributes have poured in from around the world for tragic Jordan, who loved ones have described as beautul and a shining light.In a Twitter post this morning, the England team has offered its own condolences to the schoolboy.They posted: So sad. We would like to offer our heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathies to Jordan Banksapos family and all those affected by this terrible tragedy.  The FA say they are in contact with Jordanaposs youth side, Clton Rangers Junior Football Club, and will continue to provide support to them. Liverpool, the club Jordan supported, paid their own tribute yesterday after the tragedy in Blackpool, Lancs., at around pm on Tuesday. Posting on Twitter, the club said: The thoughts of everybody at Liverpool Football Club are with Jordanaposs family and friend. Rest in peace, Jordan Banks.  Midfielder James Milner commented: A special boy taken far too soon. Jordanaposs family, from Blackpool, also spoke out yesterday for the first time since the tragedy. They said: Yesterday our worlds stopped. We lost the brightest star our beautul boy Jordan. His laugh, that infectious smile, golden curls, he was our everything.  Wise beyond his years, caring, considerate, generous and so loving. Our love is endless. Goodnight beautul boy. We thank you all for your kind words and support but as a family ask that you respect our wishes and privacy. Jordanaposs team, Clton Rangers, described him as a shining light and an inspiration who was strong, determined and courageous. Before he died Jordan was raising money for mental health services by running  miles in ten days in honour of his uncle who took his own le in . He raised £, and his efforts were congratulated by James Milner, who sent him a video congratulating him on his incredible work. A crowdfunding page set up just a day ago to support Jordanaposs family has already raised almost £,.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnEngland football teamWeather

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBolton is the UKaposs ground zero for the Indian Covid iant which has become the dominant strain in four areas, according to figures. Boris Johnson has warned the B. strain, which is currently ravaging parts of India, is of increasing concern in Britain.Official figures set to be released on Thursday are expected to confirm a worrying three fold increase in infections of the highly transmissible mutation. Experts advising the Government believe the final stage of Boris Johnsonaposs road map out of lockdown - set for June  - could now be pushed back. And it is believed that there will be an emergency meeting of the Governmentaposs SAGE advisers tomorrow to discuss the iant. Surge testing has been introduced in areas such as Bolton, Greater Manchester to help stem the spread of cases.  The Mail Online reports analysis by one of the UKaposs iant trackers has warned the strain is focused on hotspots in Bolton and nearby Blackburn with Darwen.There outbreaks are said to have grown by  and  per cent in a week, respectively, and more than half of cases found to be the Indian strain. It is also reported to be behind half of Covid infections in London, Bedford and South Northamptonshire, but these outbreaks are still small.Citing data from the Wellcome Sanger Institute The Sun reports that Bolton is the UKaposs epicentre with  positive Covid tests caused by the Indian strain up to April , representing  per cent of Covid cases in seven days. Nearby Blackburn with Darwen reportedly saw  cases identied, representing . per cent of the areaaposs total. In South Northamptonshire nearly  per cent of cases were the India iant while Bedford saw . per cent, representing  cases.Members of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies will assess the threat at a meeting today, reports i news. A member of the committee told the publication that “a delay is possible” for lockdown easing in England.  Asked about a possible delay to the June  easing, Tory minister James Cleverly told Sky News: “Scientists on SAGE will make assessments, they will report that to government, and we will make decisions based on the data, the evidence they provide. “The Prime Minister and the Health Secretary have always been clear that the easing of restrictions which allows us to get back to normality will be done at a pace and in a way that is safe. “We will always be driven by the data.” With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. COG-UK, the cross body group of experts tasked with keeping track of new mutations, is said to have identied , cases of the Indian iant. If this figure is confirmed by Public Health England in its weekly update, it would be treble the  figure from seven days earlier. Ministers have not ruled out re-introducing local lockdowns in areas where the iant of concern is increasing.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnCoronavirus

title: giant ancient werewolf chalked onto
story: :root Giant ancient werewolf chalked onto hillside to mark release of Resident Evil VillageThis ft long outline of a Lycan - an ancient werewolf - has appeared on a Somerset hillside. to celebrate the release of spooky title Resident Evil VillageGiant ancient werewolf chalked onto hillside to mark release of Resident Evil VillageThis ft long outline of a Lycan - an ancient werewolf - has appeared on a Somerset hillside. to celebrate the release of spooky title Resident Evil VillageThis ft long outline of a ‘Lycan’ - an ancient werewolf - has appeared on a Somerset hillside.Image: MC Saatchi Talk   SWNS.COMByRichard Jenkins:,  May It makes the Beast of Bodmin look like a pussycat... This ft long outline of a aposLycanapos - an ancient werewolf - has appeared on a Somerset hillside. Following more than a week of speculation regarding the artworkaposs creator, the mystery was revealed - it was a way to mark the launch of a new video game. The ft high installation celebrated the release of spooky title Resident Evil Village, the newest entry in the survival horror franchise.  It was made in the dead of night to depict one of the new enemies in the game, and even appeared to glow menacingly when the sun went down following its creation. The aposLycan,apos known for possessing superior strength, reflexes and speed, has become the latest addition to over  chalk figures scattered across the English countryside. Tsuyoshi Kanda, producer of Resident Evil Village at Capcom, said: The Resident Evil series celebrated its th anniversary in March .

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThis horror footage shows the moment a speeding Audi driver loses control and causes a car crash - injuring  people. Kamran Khan was racing his RS at more than mph over the limit when he collided with another car, which smashed into a church. More than a dozen people were injured in the terrying incident in Leeds in , including five children. Khan, , was arrested and pleaded guilty to two counts of causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He was jailed for three years during a sentencing hearing at Leeds crown court earlier this month. Got a story  Email webnews@mirror.  The court was told that Khan was driving his powerful vehicle - capable of speeds of up to mph - in wet conditions on a busy road. He then lost control and collided at speed with a Peugeot , which smashed into a Universal Church of the Kingdom of God. This vehicle hit several people, including a baby in a pram - which was trapped between the car and a wall. Most of the injuries were minor but one woman suffered a serious injury to the foot, the court was told. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  As well as a custodial sentence, Khan, from Leeds, was also banned from driving for six and a half years. PC Steve Harrison, of West Yorkshire Policeaposs Roads Policing Unit, spoke after the hearing. He said: While sentencing him, Judge Mairs repeatedly talked about Khan’s flagrant disregard for traffic laws. On that rainy day back in September , Khan chose to drive over twice the speed limit and caused a crash which injured multiple adults and children. It is sheer luck that only two people were seriously injured and that the consequences were not even more serious. The court were told Khan had a previous conviction for a drug driving offence and had cannabis in his system at the time of this collision. Khan has been jailed for his actions and I hope this sends a clear message of the dangers and consequences of driving at excessive speeds whilst under the influence of drugs.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPeugeotWest Yorkshire PoliceCCTVCCTV footageCourt caseCrown courtPrison sentenceDriving banDangerous driving

title: junk food advert ban fat
story: NewsopinionJunk food advert ban is a fat lot of good for our children without cheaper fresh foodTo win the obesity battle we need better education and pricing in the shops, Mirror columnist and guilty mum Eva Simpson arguesmirrorShareCommentsByEva Simpson:,  MAY NewsopinionKids paying the price for junk food being cheap as chips " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA ban on junk food ads on TV before pm and online completely was a positive measure ­outlined in the Queen’s Speech this week. Commercials featuring unhealthy food and snacks will no longer be shown pre-watershed and banished on the internet. It’s a signicant step, but much more needs to be donewe are to tackle Britain’s obesity crisis. Six out of  adults are overweight. The problem is particularly worrying for children. One in three leaves primary school overweight or obese. What’s really concerning is that when it comes to the bad stuff – sugar and fat – most of it is eaten at home. According to research from the ­University of Birmingham this week, ­children consume most sugar in meals prepared by their own parents. Researchers found that kids were having as much as  teaspoons of sugar every day – the equivalent of grams – which is added to food or drink or found naturally in fruit juices and honey. Cereal is one of the worst offenders. When I checked the sugar content of the cereal in my cupboard at home, I couldn’t believe I’d been buying breakfast food that contained almost  grams, the equivalent of three teaspoons of sugar, in a g serving. And let’s face it, we often eat more than g. It was a timely reminder that parents have to keep an eye on these things. It’s no good me giving my son fruit and a wholemeal cheese sandwich for lunchhe’s consuming half his sugar intake before he’s even got to school. I do think manufacturers have a key role to play. They must reduce the amount of sugar and, for that matter, salt, in food. No one needs that much. It also needs to be more affordable for parents to make nutritious meals from scratch at home. We’re constantly being told to eat more fresh fish and vegetables, for instance, but they often come with a hefty price tag compared to cheap and cheerful processed meals. Schools seem to have done a great job on this front. We no doubt have Jamie Oliver to thank for his war on Turkey Twizzlers, once a staple part of school dinners. Let’s have more education and make it easier and more affordable for families to eat well. Otherwise the tag of being the unhealthiest nation in Europe will be something we wear for a long time to come.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnFoodDietObesity

title: madeleine mccann parents 18th birthday
story: NewsMadeleine McCann parents th birthday message as they leave gts in untouched roomKate and Gerry McCann still leave gts and cards in Madeleines untouched bedroom and, on her th birthday today told their daughter we love you and are waiting for youmirrorShareByMartin Fricker:,  MAY NewsMadeleine McCann turned  on Wednesday " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeMadeleine McCann’s parents vowed on her th birthday today: “We’re never going to give up”. Kate and Gerry McCann still hope she will be found alive,  years after she vanished on holiday in Portugal in , days before her fourth birthday. They said in a poignant message: “We love you and are waiting for you.” Devoted Kate and Gerry marked daughter Madeleine’s th birthday on Wednesday by leaving cards and gts in her room, untouched since she vanished  years ago. The couple posted a photo of her on the Find Madeleine campaign Facebook page, writing alongside it: “Happy th birthday Madeleine.  “We love you and we’re waiting for you and we’re never going to give up.” Kate, , and Gerry, , had asked pals to mark the day in a low-key manner. The Facebook post came a week after they marked the “particularly poignant” th anniversary of her disappearance. Madeleine went missing from her family’s holiday apartment in the Algarve resort of Praia da Luz days before her fourth birthday in May .  Prosecutors want to question German paedophile Christian Brueckner over her disappearance and claim to have evidence that she is dead. But Kate and Gerry, , of Rothley, Leics, refuse to give up hope that Madeleine is still alive and will one day be found. In another post on the Find Madeleine page last week they said they “need to know what happened to our lovely daughter”. Scotland Yard’s hunt for Madeleine’s abductor continues, with four detectives still working on Operation Grange.  A top-level summit between German, British and Portuguese detectives is due to take place in Lisbon this summer. The Mirror revealed in January that cops are launching a push to find the “missing piece of the jigsaw” that could snare Brueckner. German and Portuguese investigators are to carry out new interviews of key witnesses in the Algarve who knew him. Brueckner, , was named as the prime suspect for Madeleine’s disappearance by German prosecutors last June.  They believe he abducted and killed the three-year-old. He is currently serving a seven-year term in a prison in Hanover for raping a pensioner in Praia da Luz in . His lawyer Friedrich Fulscher insists the German has nothing to do with the youngster’s disappearance. Last week the couple posted on Facebook: “Every May is tough – a reminder of years passed, of years together lost, or stolen.  “This year it is particularly poignant as we should be celebrating Madeleine’s th birthday. Enough said. “The Covid pandemic has made this year even more dficult for many reasons but thankfully the investigation to find Madeleine and her abductor has continued. “We hang on to the hope, however small, that we will see Madeleine again. “As we have said repeatedly, we need to know what has happened to our lovely daughter, no matter what. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  “We are very grateful to the police for their continued efforts. “We still receive so many positive words and good wishes despite the years that have gone by. “It all helps and for that we are truly grateful – thank you. Kate and Gerry.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorMore OnScotland YardMadeleine MccannGerry McCannPoliceKate McCannBirthday partyMissing persons

title: monster belgravia who slayed old
story: :root Monster of Belgravia who slayed old ladies and butchered priest wont be freedEXCLUSIVE: Patrick Mackay, dubbed the Monster of Belgravia, slaughtered two pensioners and butchered a priest with an axe - the son of a victim of an unsolved murder said everybody knows hes killed moreMonster of Belgravia who slayed old ladies and butchered priest wont be freedEXCLUSIVE: Patrick Mackay, dubbed the Monster of Belgravia, slaughtered two pensioners and butchered a priest with an axe - the son of a victim of an unsolved murder said everybody knows hes killed morePatrick Mackays crimes shocked Britain in the sImage: PA Archive PA ImagesByTom Pettor:,  May One of Britainaposs longest serving prisoners will remain in jail  years after completing his minimum sentence, the parole board has ruled. Patrick Mackay, , dubbed the “Monster of Belgravia”, strangled two old ladies and butchered a Catholic priest with an axe.But Mackay confessed to eight more killings - then denied it. All of the attacks remain unsolved. Police were asked to probe the cases in , delaying his parole hearing. The board has now decided not to make findings of fact in relation to those cases due to the “passage of time” and “absence of complete evidence”. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  It said in a decision summary released on Thursday: “The  found that it should consider some of the allegations but decided that these did not affect its assessment of Mr Mackay’s risk.” Mackay was  when he was convicted of strangling and stabbing Isabella Grfiths, , in Belgravia, central London in  and Adele Price, , a year later. He was further convicted of murdering -year-old Catholic priest Anthony Crean in the Kent village of Shorne in .  Mackay, who has changed his name to David Groves, was jailed for le for manslaughter, by reasons of diminished responsibility. Another  offences were taken into consideration by the trial judge, including robberies and thefts. He had also been charged with two further murders, which denied committing, which were ordered by the trial judge to “lie on file”.  MacKay has been in open conditions since . The  said it considered a dossier of more that  pages and heard evidence from his probation officer, the official supervising his case in prison, a psychologist and an independent psychologist. The parole board said: “After considering the circumstances of his offending, the progress made while in custody and the evidence presented at the hearings, the  was not satisfied that Mr Mackay was suitable for release.  “However, on assessing the benefits and risks of Mr Mackay remaining in open conditions, the  recommended that he should stay in the open estate.” Among the unsolved murders Mackay admitted and then denied was that of cafe owner Ivy Davies, , who was axed to death at her home in Southend, Essex, in February .The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.

title: prince harry feels free california
story: NewsPrince Harry feels free in Calornia and takes Archie out on back of bikeThe Duke of Sussex, Prince Harry, was speaking on the Armchair Expert podcast about his le in Calornia, on the west coast of the US, away from the royal familymirrorShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyReporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPrince Harry, pictured with we Meghan Markle, said he feels dferent in Calornia in the US " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrince Harry feels free in Calornia and is able to take Archie out on back of his bike, he has said on a podcast. The Duke spoke about how his le changed since quitting as a senior member of the royal family and moving to America with Meghan and now two-year-old Archie. Harry, , said in London he became used to making constant attempts to stay under the radar while out and about - often wearing baseball caps and walking with his head lowered. In a bid to keep themselves out of the spotlight, Harry revealed he and Meghan even met in disguise at a supermarket for one of their dates.He said they pretended not to know each other to try and stay aposincognitoapos, adding: I had a baseball cap on, looking down at the floor, trying to stay incognito. Itaposs amazing how much chewing gum you see, itaposs a mess!  But, Harry said his Calornian le couldnapost be more dferent and is able to lt his head. Speaking on the Armchair Expert podcast, he said: Living here now I can lt my head. I feel dferent, my shoulders have dropped. You can walk around feeling a bit more free. I take Archie out on the back of my bike.. The Prince recently said Calornia has now become his spiritual home where the anger of the past has gone, a journalist who once interviewed the duke has claimed. Journalist, author and mental health advocate Bryony Gordon said that the Duke of Sussex now had a sense of purpose after his move to the US.  Bryony previously got Harry to open up about his mental health battle in the wake of Princess Dianaaposs death in her podcast in .In an article for the Dailyshe said that Harry, now living in a  million mansion in Montecito with his pregnant we Meghan and son Archie, had found a sense of purpose after leaving the Firm last year. She said: The anger of the past has gone, and it has been replaced with a sense of purpose. Calornia is not just Harry’s physical home for now – it is also his spiritual one, where nobody thinks anything of openly discussing their struggles.And the Prince Harry we can’t see is perhaps the one we don’t want to – the one who is getting on just fine, happily following his own path outside the conventions we are used to seeing him in. Hiking. Taking the dogs to the beach. Harry recently ed to America after a brief visit to the UK to attend Prince Philipaposs funeral. But, despite the short reunion with brother William, the pair are reportedly still not talking and their relationship remains frosty.The Princesapos ongoing rt is said to have widened after Harry and Meghanaposs bombshell tell-all interview with American TV host Oprah Winfrey.  In it, Harry claimed his brother and father, Charles, were apostrappedapos in their roles within the Royal Family. Despite briefly reconnecting at Prince Philipaposs funeral, sources claim the brothers are still not talking, according to royal writer Nick Bullen. The editor of True Royalty TV told US Magazine : All of my sources tell me that they are not talking at the moment. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. However, Bullen claims that despite the relationship remaining frosty, their brief reunion at the Duke of Edinburghaposs funeral is a step in the right direction. He also claimed Kate Middleton was also playing her role in helping reunite the feuding princes, adding: Itaposs pretty clear the Duchess of Cambridge was doing her best to build the bridges.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPrince HarryRoyal FamilyMeghan MarkleArchie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor

title: prince harry shares 3 times
story: NewsPrince Harry details the three times he felt truly helpless and needed therapyPrince Harry said he felt "completely helpless" in three moments of his le including when he was being chased by the paparazzi while in the car with his mum Diana and when he was in AfghanistanmirrorShareCommentsByTim HanlonClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPrince Harry has revealed the three moments he felt completely helpless in his le " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrince Harry has spoken of the three times in his le where he felt truly helpless as he opened up about how he has sought therapy for anger management.The Duke of Sussex, , said he used to repress the anger connected to the constraints of being part of The Firm and the inevitable media glare that came with it.It was only thanks to a conversation with his we Meghan, , that he realised he needed help, he told Dax Shepard on the Armchair Expert podcast. Recollecting that moment, he said: It was a conversation that I had with my now we, and she saw, she saw it straight away. She could tell that I was hurting and that some of the stuff that was out of control was making me really angry and it would make my blood boil. .  Harry, who now lives in Santa Barbara with Meghan, told the Armchair Expert podcast: Helplessness, that is my biggest Achilles heel. There were three major times that I felt completely helpless [as a royal], one when I was a kid in the back of a car with my mum being chased by paparazzi, two was in Afghanistan in an apache helicopter and then the third one was with my we [having the conversation about therapy].  Harry and Meghan explosively announced last year that they were quitting their lives as senior royals to move to Calornia with their son Archie, now two. He told the podcast: In my early s it was a case of I don’t want this job, I don’t want to be here, I don’t want to be doing this. Look what it did to my mum, how will I be able to settle down, have a we and a family when I know that it is going to happen again because I know. I’ve seen behind the curtain, I’ve seen the business model how this operation runs and how it works, I don’t want to be a part of this.  Then when I started doing therapy suddenly the bubble was burst […] you are in this position of privilege, stop complaining or behaving as though you want something dferent, make this dferent. Harry also revealed he met we Meghan in a supermarket and compared his le as a Royal Family member to The Truman Show, the Daily Star reports. The interview with Dax comes two months after the Sussexesapos bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, in which the couple spoke about the issues they had within the Royal Family. In the interview, first aired on CBS and then ITV, Harry and Meghan explosively claimed concerns were raised by a senior member of the royal family over how dark their son Archieaposs skin tone would be.Oprah then followed up on the conversation saying it was neither the Queen or Prince Philip who had made the remark.Meghan also told the US chat star how she felt like The Firm had failed to give her the support she needed when she felt suicidal pregnant with her son. After suffering a miscarriage last July, the two are now expecting a baby girl in the summertime.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnCBS CorporationDax ShepardPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghOprah WinfreyPrincess DianaPrince HarryPregnancyRoyal FamilyMental healthMiscarriageTherapy

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrincess Charlotte is set for a series of dramatic title changes when her grandad Charles and later her dad William become king, say royal experts. There will be some major shake-ups in the Royal Family when the Queenaposs reign comes to an end, and several senior members will be in line for new titles and new roles when Charles ascends to the throne. Charlotte, who turned six earlier this month and is fourth in line to the throne, could eventually inherit her great aunt Princess Anneaposs title. The Princess Royal title is traditionally given to the eldest daughter of the monarch, but it doesnapost happen automatically and it is up to William to decide whether Charlotte inherits the title. Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here Regardless of who is king in the future, Charlotte will always retain the style of Royal Highness.Until then, she will have a number of title changes during the reigns of Charles and William. When Charles becomes king, she will become Princess Charlotte of Cambridge and Cornwall and likely Princess Charlotte of Wales when her father becomes the Princes of Wales. But she would lose the Princess of Wales title when William becomes king and her older brother George inherits the Prince of Wales title.  Instead, she wouldto being Princess Charlotte.Her mum Kate Middleton would become the Queen Consort, though she is likely to be referred to as Queen Catherine. The celebrity gossip YouTube channel OSSA explained Charlotteaposs future will only change dramatically when her father succeeds his grandfather as king.  It added: “When that happens le as Charlotte knows it will look very dferent, in fact, there is a good chance she’ll lose her titles when her dad is on the throne. “By the time William is King of England, his eldest son George will be Prince of Wales. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. The young royal would become Charlotte of nothing, the report added. OSSA said: “Her right to be Princess of Wales flies out the window when her brother gets the official title of Prince of Wales because a royal lady can only be a princessshe’s married to a prince or the daughter of a prince. “As George’s sister, Charlotte doesn’t fit either category.” Charlotte could become Princess Royal when William is king. The Princess Royal title comes with a lot of responsibilities and strict rules to abide by, especially when it comes to dating. Under ancient British law, anyone who sleeps with the Princess Royal before getting married to her is guilty of treason, which was once punishable by execution, royal expert Duncan Larcombe has explained in the past. He reckons it is most likely that dad William will bestow Charlotte with the Princess Royal title once she marries. Mr Larcombe previously told Town and Country: The title of Princess Royal is traditionally bestowed on the eldest daughter of the monarch. Princess Anne had to wait until  before her mother the queen bestowed the title of Princess Royal on her, even though the title had been vacant since .FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPrincess CharlottePrince Charles, Prince of WalesPrince WilliamRoyal FamilyThe Queen

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA thirsty punter ended up hanging upside down on a pubaposs railings after trying to sneak into its beer garden to grab an empty bench by clambering over a fence. Pub-goers were left in hysterics after witnessing the embarrassing mishap as they enjoyed their drinks at The Hope and Anchor in Royton, Greater Manchester. Stunned onlooker Nicole Meadows was enjoying a drink at her local on Friday evening when she spotted the daring duo attempting to land a vacant bench. In the hilarious clip, one of the women attempts to step over the fence but appears to get her foot stuck and is trying to disentangle herself from that while her pal decided to e over herself. The second woman flings herself over the railing but the waist of her jeans becomes caught on the metalwork, flipping her the wrong way up and leaving her suspended upside down for more than  seconds.  As -year-old Nicole and other witnesses cackle in the background, the unknown woman is finally helped back over the fence by a stranger who comes to help. Once freed from her predicament, the woman announces aposIaposve hurt my vaginaapos to entertained customers before askingshe can have a seatshe walks around to the proper entrance. Nicole, from Middleton, Greater Manchester, said: It was hilarious. Iaposve never seen anything like that before. It was highly amusing. Everybody was laughing. Theyaposd closed the doors because the pub was full, but there were still a couple of empty benches outside.  The girls were trying to climb over the fence to sit at one of the benches and get served. The doors were closed and there was a sign outside saying they were at full capacity on a blackboard. But itaposs an open beer garden and you can see [the seating]. The first girl managed to get over, but the second one didnapost.  The care worker had been with her mum Vicky Meadows when the chaotic scene caught the attention of the entire beer garden, who all watched on in amusement. In her clip, Nicole can be heard laughing hysterically as the two unknown women became stuck in the awkward positions. Nicole said: Everyoneaposs going wild because everythingaposs reopened. Itaposs got a really big beer garden. Somebody sat at the back of the pub [got up to] try and help her over. [After the incident] she just accepted the fact they werenapost allowed in and tried going somewhere .  I think she wrapped her legs around it to try and save herself from smashing her face open. Margaret Newton, landlady of The Hope and Anchor, said she asked the two women to come back another time and was glad they didnapost come to any harm. Margaret said: The door was shut, she tried to get in and she wasnapost served. Thataposs the only thing I can say. I told her to come back later on when it might have died down, but she didnapost do. I havenapost seen her since. I did ask her to come back. I said aposwe are full love. Iaposm not serving youapos. Iaposm just glad she didnapost hurt herself. Itaposs a light-hearted story. I have no problems. They do tend to climb over the fence. If they climb over the fence, the rule is they donapost get served. Iaposll just be glad when we can get back to normal. Weaposll be able to welcome people back in and save all this hassle.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPubs

title: queens tribute philip touching choice
story: NewsQueens tribute to Philip with touching choice of dress for State Opening of ParliamentRoyal fans noticed the Queens outfit choice for the State Opening of Parliament held a special signicance and tribute to the Duke of EdinburghmirrorShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  MAY NewsThe Queen delivering the Queens Speech " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Queen paid a touching tribute to Prince Philip with her dress choice for the State Opening of Parliament. On Tuesday, Her Majesty outlined promises from the Government as she carried out her first major public ceremonial duty since the death of her husband. Fans noticed her outfit choice held a special signicance and tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.A tweet from a royal fan pointed out: The Queen is wearing the same dress she wore on the photograph released for Prince Philip ’s th birthday.For the Queenaposs Speech, the Queen wore a long blue coat with a matching dress adorned with yellow flowers, and a coordinating blue hat, by Angela Kelly.  It was the same dress the Queen wore in a portrait of her and the Duke of Edinburgh on his th and final birthday. For the first time in  years, the consortaposs throne that is usually placed next to the monarch for the event was absent, following the sad death of Prince Philip last month. Instead Prince Charles followed his late fatheraposs example to take his motheraposs hand and provide support during the formal event.  But it meant that much like Philipaposs funeral, the Queen was pictured alone in a striking reminder of her sad loss. The ceremony did not have all of the pomp and circumstance of a normal State Opening, with no horse-drawn carriages or page boys. Much of its pageantry was missing because of Covid restrictions still in place despite the easing of lockdown measures in England.  The Queen set out the Governmentaposs post-pandemic agenda outlining a raft of new laws the PM hopes will help him fulfil his promise to tackle inequality and level up the country. It included promises to receive more tailored and preventative care through the NHS, to provide measures to tackle obesity and mental health and to bring proposals on social reform forward. She also said proposals will be brought forward to create and support jobs, to support a letime skills guarantee and to help businesses drive economic growth.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnState Opening of ParliamentThe QueenPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRoyal FamilyPolitics

title: school rang mum five lay
story: NewsSchool rang mum-of-five as she lay dying to say she was late picking up kids‘Loving soul’ Iram Shehzadi, , was on her way to pick up her seven-year-old daughter from school in Bradford, West Yorkshire, when she was mowed down just  yards from her homemirrorShareByMark Lister:,  MAY NewsFlowers are laid at the scene of the tragedy just metres from the victims family home in Bradford " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice A mum-of-five killed in an alleged hit and run was called by her kidsapos school as she lay dying to say she was late picking up her child, it is claimed. ‘Loving soul’ Iram Shehzadi, , was on her way to collect her daughter when she was struck in Bradford, West Yorkshire, on Monday afternoon. As paramedics worked in vain to save her le her mobile rang as the school called to ask why she was running late to pick up her child, a witness to the horric crash claims. Police are quizzing  -year-old driver arrested on suspicion of the murder of Mrs Shehzad, who died less than  yards from her home.The mum died when a grey Citroen C ploughed into her near a junction in the neighbourhood, police say. A man who raced to the scene after hearing the crash described a bloodbath, as the victim was carried on the bonnet before the vehicle crashed into boulders beside a grassed area and she was catapulted -ft, hitting a tree head-first. A -year-old man was arrested a short time later, West Yorkshire Police said. Mrs Shehzadi, has an -year-old son, along with two boys and two girls. She was taking her usual daily route to pick up the youngest, her seven-year-old daughter, when she was killed at pm. Uzmat Munir, , a bank employee, was working from his home overlooking the grassed area on Monday afternoon when he heard a massive bang. “I saw the lady laying face down on the grass next to the tree. The car was empty and smashed into the rocks, he said. “My neighbour called an ambulance and we tried to help the lady, but none of us knew CPR. “There was about five of us stood around, not knowing what to do. A woman came before the ambulance arrived and turned her over and tried to revive her, but the poor lady was obviously dead.There was blood flowing from her mouth and a head wound - it was a bloodbath. “The car had hit her, carried on the bonnet and after it hit the rocks, she had flown into the tree. It looked like she had hit her head on the tree.”  Flowers have since laid below the tree, and police remained in the area on Wednesday. Mr Munir added:“I heard that whilst the paramedics tried to resuscitate the woman, her mobile phone rang, and it was the school ringing to let her know she was late picking her kid up.” The victimaposs neighbour Rukhsana Kausar, , said: ”She lived with her husband and five children and was devoted to her children. “Iram had gone to pick up her young daughter, like she does every day at that time, and this terrible thing has happened.” Rehana Nawaz, , who lives on the street where the mum was hit, said: ”I heard a lot of noise and thought it was a fight at first. “I went down and saw her laying down on the ground, face down. I asked a couple of guys standing there to roll her over onto her back. “You could see she had a massive injury to the right side of her head and there was a lot of blood coming from her mouth. “My sister-in-law, who is a teacher and knows CPR, tried about  compressions and then the ambulance arrived. “At first I thought she had been the driver of the car and I saw car keys on the ground beside the vehicle, but the I was told by someone there that the driver had run off. “One of the men who was first on the scene had held her hand and she looked at him as she took her last breath and passed away. “She took that same route every day at the same time to pick up her little girl.” Haris, Mrs Shehzadi’s nephew, said: “It has hit the family, especially her children, really hard. “She was a very good lady who always kept herself to herself. She has helped everybody out. She had a lot of respect from the area. “I used to live near her and see her every day going to pick up her kids from school. “The family are going to be traumatised, she did not deserve this at all.” Another relative said: I went to pay my respects to her husband yesterday and he is still in shock. He still thinks she is coming back, it hasnapost sunk in yet. She was a beautul, kind, loving soul who will always remain in our heart. A cousin, Shab Lush, said: ”She was on her way to school to collect her daughter not knowing what was ahead. Sheaposs gone in this beautul month of Ramadan.” Chief Inspector Daniel Ware, of Bradford District Police, said: “We are continuing to investigate this fatal collision and are supporting the victim’s family at what is clearly a devastating time for them. “I want to thank residents and witnesses who have come forward with information to support the police investigation, and continue to urge witnesses who we may not have spoken with to contact us. “Anyone who can assist our enquiries with information and dashcam or CCTV phone footage is asked to contact West Yorkshire Police via  or online using www.westyorkshire.police.uk livechat quoting log  of  .” FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorMore OnWest Yorkshire PoliceCar crashes

title: woman transforms ordinary looking home
story: NewsWoman transforms ordinary looking home into incredible s replica with time-warp interiorCrossing the threshold to Hannah Halls home in Nottingham is like stepping back in time, with a s interior complete with patterned wallpaper, vintage furniture and a rotary phonemirrorShareCommentsByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  MAY NewsThe house looks ordinary from the outside " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA woman has transformed her home into an incredible time capsule that feels like youaposre stepping back into the s. Hannah Hall bought a s-era home in Nottingham with her mum and began fitting out the interior with a decor from another era, such as patterned wallpaper, old appliances and vintage furniture. The kitchen includes black and white tiled flooring, a whistle kettle, exposed wooden beams and an open pantry, and where thereaposs a working rotary phone and a stunning oak wardrobe.aposVintage-obsessedapos Hannah originally bought a working s gas cooker on eBay and has slowly given the home a makeover to match the theme, saying her interest in the wartime period was sparked when her grandparents introduced her to the fashion, film and TV of the time. Her grandparents gave her some of the furniture which now features in the home, and Hannah says - despite owning a TV - she plans to continue to strip back the home instead of turning to modern technology. Hannah said: Iaposve always been interested in vintage things and I get told that Iaposm an old head on young shoulders. When me and my mum moved into the house, it was totally dferent to what it is now and we wanted to unearth its potential. Itaposs my mumaposs first buy because sheaposs always rented homes, so I wanted to make it extra special. The theme really started to take off when we did the kitchen in a s style and we loved it so much that we decided we really wanted to go with that theme throughout the house.  The kitchenaposs finishing touch was the beautul s gas cooker - it works an absolute dream and has inspired us to live a little simpler. The house is kind of like an ode to my grandpa, who was born in . He was a signicant part of my le and really got me interested in the s era as a kid - I was enamoured by his droplets of wisdom. My nanaposs taste in vintage and eccentric fashion has also inspired me to dress quirky. I feel like my home is an adoption centre for vintage things. I absolutely love it but I know itaposs not to everyoneaposs taste because itaposs a massive niche.  After the kitchen was redone, we went a bit mad and just started collecting dferent items such as a -year-old tin opener, vintage wallpaper and old paintings. The gas cooker in the kitchen definitely comes in handythe electricity goes out on our street because weaposre still able to cook dinner. Itaposs not what you expect when you come in and every single room has vintage touches. Our family thinks the house is really quirky and is like a little time capsule. Everyone loves coming over and kicking it a little old school for a bit.  Hannah says when they bought the home from an old family friend everywhere was rather beige and needed an overhaul having lost its charm. The renovation work uncovered the original floorboards and staircase, which bought it back to le a bit.While continuing to add to her s home, Hannah posts videos of the project on her @Realvintagedollshouse TikTok account, saying: Vintage items have a bit more soul than modern things and I get a kick out of finding something that might have so much story behind it.Iaposm a big believer that we should honour the past and I donapost think younger people these days necessarily appreciate how dferent things used to be. Reminding people that it wasnapost always like this hopefully helps them appreciate how far weaposve come. Weaposre still working on the house every day and weaposre hoping to get a s-style front door and also transform the back garden, using my grandpaaposs old Raleigh bike as a flower feature.What do you think of the home  Let us know in the comments. The West Berkshire Brewery is offering the chance for you to rename a London pub in your dadaposs honour for Fatheraposs Day .You can nominate your dad, or a special father figure in your le and have the Oxford Tavern in Kentish Town become an ode to them thanks to the WBB. Andthat werenapost enough, the pub will also be offering free pints of Good Old Dad to fathers who visit throughout the day. The winning entry shall not only have the pub renamed, but theyaposll also be able to keep the sign as a memory of the day.
